title: So ekko has enough cc and utility to be played as a tank in the LCS
body:

It's the CS guys; it gives people a huge advantage when you have a champ that even a cat walking across a keyboard can clear a wave with versus a champ like lux who can barely clear a wave with a single skill with a max build.

Your mixing up overloaded and overpowered. In Katarina's case she was overpowered during the tankarina era. Her numbers were too high which is why she was abusing a tank build. The numbers were lowered and ratio's raised and tankarina died as a result. 

In Ekko's case it's overloaded. He is being played in multiple roles at the same time, and excelling at them precisely because his kit has so much in it. He can go tank due to his CC and utility; things neccessary for tanks to excel. He is also destroying as an assassin because he has the mobility and damage of an assassin to allow him to burst. 

And to be clear here, there is a difference between ekko and tankarina when it comes to tankyness. Katarina was being built TANKY but she was not a tank. A tank's role is engage for a team as well as peel through cc. Kat has no cc to speak up and she can't engage for a team (she can engage for herself only). In Ekko's case he is being built as a tank and fulfilling the role of tank for a team through his engage and cc. 

It's why you wouldn't classify a caitlyn for example who is built full tank, as the same as a malphite being full tank. Their both tanky but only one can fulfill the tanks job of engage/peel/cc/etc.
He has way too much CC for being an assassin. People say that tanks are all OP because of CC but to be honest, there's more CC on Ekko than most tanks.

So the guy below says it pretty well, but there is a big difference between too much damage and too much utility with damage.

on the other hand ekkos ult has a litteral do not walk here indicator its enough that they even show you the ghost rather than makeing you remember where ekko was 4 seconds ago and his movement pattern how much do you want riot to hold your hand. 
i think the slow and speed up on ekkos passive is nice and acurate representation of his character but ekkos q e and r already does high damage there is no need for a passive that does equal amount of damage to an active spell of an assassin and its up every 3 seconds where is the assassination in that.

The problem is, they gave him 2 very unreliable skills (stun and ult) so they gave him huge rewards for hitting them, then gave the rest of his kit enough power to still be able to fight (though not as well) after missing both the stun and the ult damage part. People already hate on Morgana's binding, Ekko has the same duration stun with AOE. And he has the range to set the stun up out of sight, then blink in at the last moment.
To some point you have to argue execution difficulty vs power.

The issue with that is that at the highest levels people can be expected to play near perfectly.  All of the recently released champs are good examples of high power in exchange for high difficulty, and all of them are top of the line picks in pro play.

It was the whole Lee Sin thing way back when he first started getting nerfed.  He was too hard to really show his power but once people started playing him to his potential he was pretty much everywhere at high levels of play.  Releasing champs like that (how many recent champs have they released that wouldn't fall under that?  Ekko yes, Bard yes, Rek'sai maybe not so much, Kalista yes, Azir yes, Gnar yes, all popular picks at high level) eclipses other choices.

unlike most of them though, look at the difficulty of ekko's ultimate when used for damage not healing or escape, aswell as using his W for more than just a shield.  His Dash and projectile and passive are a bit too strong though.

I don't think it's really any different.  Take some of Ekko's utility and exchange it for damage, take some of his shields/heals and exchange it for damage... now he looks like Kat did.  Both of their kits are/were overbudgeted, Kat's power was just distributed more obviously.
I remember back when people complained Rito was trying too hard to kill build diversity by only allowing champions to do one particular role.

youre taking 2 events in isolation and not considering the consequences when both happen. 

Yes, people might have complained about killing build diversity, but it ended up happening - champions were forced into one role. Now that most of our champions are neatly packaged into one role each (for the most part), they release a champion that excels at many roles. Either force all the champions into one role or allow all the champions to have some diversity.

there is no either or the only reason champions cant play one role or another is because players dont want to chance trying to play a champion where he may not be percivied as belonging there  like natalus was a year ago i was branded a troll for carrying him bot as a tank and feeding the hell out of my adc with my high base damages root slow knock up and pull

Annie gets played as support - nerfed in attack range and base damage, and ratios got improved. 
Zyra gets played as support - base damage nerf, ratios improve. 
Veigar played as support -no more immediate stun, but double Q farm
Maokai gets played top - heath regen nerfed, damage nerfed. 
Naut played as support - shield and damage gets nerfed early, shield scales harder lategame with items.
Pantheon gets played in the jungle - attack speed nerfed. 
Wukong gets played in jungle - nerfed (though for him, he got nerfed in all his roles, not just the one that became FoTM). 

Face it dude. When a champion gets played in a role they arent supposed to play, most of the time they get hit with nerfs that only affect that one role, then get some compensation for their 'normal' role.

Edit - forgot Fiddle, who got nerfed in his CC and passive once he got played as support.

It's one of those things where one camp of people loves that champions can carry out multiple rules while another camp hates that idea that certain champions can excel in more than one. I, for example, don't mind that Ekko can do multiple roles if he's built for them. Current overtuned damage aside, that's actually pretty cool to be either a tank or an assassin. That versatility could potentially allow him to be a nice wildcard pick that doesn't reveal your team's strategy immediately and I like that, as I do for a lot of versatile picks. But on the other hand, I can easily see how other people might see that he can do two seemingly contradictory roles as being a little overbearing since even as an assassin he's going to retain that same utility and cc, even if it's used in a different manner. 

Kind of like how some people absolutely hate Lulu top but don't mind her as a support, or how others absolutely hated Soraka, Sona or Janna mid but didn't hate them as supports. They used their strengths and went into a solo lane with them despite their fairly large downsides, until that secondary role was nerfed (Soraka couldn't Infuse herself with mana and lost Starcall damage, Janna lost tornado damage, Sona lost.. well, Sona just plain lost) and they were forced back into their primary because of it. When you look at cases like that, and a few others I'm certain that I'm forgetting, it's kind of easy to believe Riot has a set place or two that they planned for a champion to go, and if they deviate from that then they receive nerfs until they step back in line. I'm never sure how I feel about that.

I don't exactly see what is wrong with a champion being able to perform in several different roles. Champions that are problems are not ones that can effectively do two different things but champs that can do two or more things at the same time effectively.

Having different building paths isn't necessarily overloaded, but being overloaded can lead to different build paths.

I mean, several melee champions like Vi (in her defense, she doesn't have a W active, so she does trade something for that passive) can be built somewhere between tanky and damage-y to fit the game they're in and the situation.

I don't argue that Ekko isn't overloaded, just that he has counterplay and it's pretty reasonable. Does that justify him being overloaded? Not really, but all I wanted to do was say that it's not uncommon for melee champions to have different ways to build.

> (in her defense, she doesn't have a W active, so she does trade something for that passive)

What about Gnar? And Diana? Gnar has the max health damage + movement speed. Diana has just the flat damage as AOE. Vi has max health damage, gains attack speed, and reduces enemy's armor.

Diana has a shield, deals magic damage per orb, and then gets the shield refreshed if she lands all the orbs that stacks with the current shield. Gnar also happens to be ranged though, not melee unless in mega form.

Yeah, Vi's W could be a little less, but at least it's not a passive on top of an active. That's all I was saying.

He's only played as a tank because he's a flex pick. Have you seen him perform as a tank? It's sub-par to say the least. Luckily for him, LCS junglers aren't supposed to offer anything but utility and damage soaking later on.

Okay, who argued he wasn't overtuned? Sure, his kit is powerful and it did need a bit of a tap, but there's no way we can stop him from being Overtuned at this point. I even kept telling people he isn't overpowered, just overtuned. You give anyone too much of course they're going to seem powerful. I think lowering his base damages might help benefit that? As he has a lot of base damage to use, which is why tank-ekko is so rewarding.
